page.title: 14Limestone and Drystone Walls
page.content: {Limestone}is composed of egg-like granules of crystalline calcite. {Cotswold stone}is only found in this area and is quarried. If the rock is not quarried at the right time it may flake or crumble from frost. The houses are very distinguished in this area because they are made of this stone.{St. Lawrence's Church}was built in 1784 and over the years the stone has survived, although masonry work was done in 1977-78. Limestone {crumbles}and{deteriorates}through age, rain and air-pollution. Pigeon House, Sherborne Terrace, was built in the 14th century and has also survived. {Drystone walls}are used on farms to divide up fields and are still in use on{Moore Lane Farm.}These days people like to use the walls in gardens and landscapes because they are so picturesque.
